elements.content: An isomeric series of NS2-macrocycles, incorporating ortho- ( o -L), meta- ( m -L), and para-xylyl ( p -L) groups in their backbones between the sulfur donors, have been synthesized. A comparative investigation of the coordination behavior of these macrocyclic ligands with silver(I) salts is reported. The X-ray structures of six complexes (1–6) were determined, and a variety of structural types that range from cyclic oligomers to zigzag or helical chains is shown to occur. Reactions of o -L with silver nitrate and perchlorate afforded three complexes with different topologies: the cyclic hexamer [Ag6( o -L)6](NO3)6·0.5DMF·7H2O (1), the cyclic hexamer with two terminal complex units [Ag8( o -L)8](ClO4)8 (2), and a one-dimensional (1D) zigzag coordination polymer of type {[Ag2( o -L)2](ClO4)2·2CH3CN·CHCl3} n (3). Reaction of m -L with silver(I) perchlorate gave the 1D zigzag coordination polymer, {[Ag( m -L)]ClO4·CH2Cl2} n (4). Reaction of p -L with silver perchlorate yielded a crystalline product whose X-ray analysis confirmed it to be a mixture of two different species: the discrete helical complex {[Ag3( p -L)3](ClO4)3} n (5) and the cyclic tetramer [Ag4( p -L)4(ClO4)4]·3DMF (6). The influence of macrocyclic ring flexibility and sulfur donor atom spacing on the topologies adopted by the respective complexes is discussed.

elements.content: The field of metallosupramolecular chemistry based on macrocyclic ligand systems has reached a stage where it has frequently been possible to influence a given self-assembly process such that a desired complex type results. For example, it has been well demonstrated that the use of thioether-containing macrocycles as building blocks can promote the formation of new coordination oligomeric and polymeric (including framework systems) as a consequence of the unique exocoordinating tendencies of this donor atom type. Thus exocoordination of the sulfur donors offers the prospect of employing either a single metal or metal-containing bridge species to link macrocyclic building blocks.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

The field of metallosupramolecular chemistry based on macrocyclic ligand systems has reached a stage where it has frequently been possible to influence a given self-assembly process such that a desired complex type results. For example, it has been well demonstrated that the use of thioether-containing macrocycles as building blocks can promote the formation of new coordination oligomeric and polymeric (including framework systems) as a consequence of the unique exocoordinating tendencies of this donor atom type. Thus exocoordination of the sulfur donors offers the prospect of employing either a single metal or metal-containing bridge species to link macrocyclic building blocks.

elements.content: We have demonstrated that the exocoordination of thioether donors in mixed S/O or S/O/N donor macrocycles, coupled with counteranion and solvent variation, afforded diverse types of supramolecular complexes  that, for example, included an unusual cyclic oligomeric silver(I) species. Thus, the careful selection of a particular thia-containing macrocycle can, in principle, be used to direct the formation of a range of different coordination topologies; a variety of such complexes involving thioether exocoordination have now been reported by us and others. As part of our studies, we have employed a strategy for moderating the topologies of such metallosupramolecular species that involves stepwise variation of the backbone of a given ligand type in order to probe structure–function relationships in the resulting complexes.
elements.clean_text: We have demonstrated that the exocoordination of thioether donors in mixed S/O or S/O/N donor macrocycles, coupled with counteranion and solvent variation, afforded diverse types of supramolecular complexes  that, for example, included an unusual cyclic oligomeric silver(I) species. Thus, the careful selection of a particular thia-containing macrocycle can, in principle, be used to direct the formation of a range of different coordination topologies; a variety of such complexes involving thioether exocoordination have now been reported by us and others. As part of our studies, we have employed a strategy for moderating the topologies of such metallosupramolecular species that involves stepwise variation of the backbone of a given ligand type in order to probe structure-function relationships in the resulting complexes.

elements.content: We have also extended the above approaches to include the use of isomeric sulfur-containing macrocycles for the construction of new supramolecular complexes and, in particular, new cyclic oligomeric complexes. In these studies we observed that the reaction of the thiophilic silver(I) and mercury(II) ions with the isomeric NS2-macrocyclic ligands, o -L, m -L, and p -L (Chart ) incorporating ortho-, meta-, and para-xylyl subunits result in major structural differences between the respective metal complex products, especially when viewed at the supramolecular level. In particular, these complexes exhibited a range of topologies that included assemblies featuring very different flower-like cyclic oligomeric and leaf-like one-dimensional (1D) chain configurations. More recently, we also synthesized silver(I) and mercury(II) complexes of the m -L macrocycle which also gave rise to different coordination modes and topologies. For example, an unusual silver(I)/palladium(II) heterobinuclear complex forming a two-dimensional (2D) network was also obtained in which [cis-Cl2Pd( m -L)] acts as a metalloligand.
elements.clean_text: We have also extended the above approaches to include the use of isomeric sulfur-containing macrocycles for the construction of new supramolecular complexes and, in particular, new cyclic oligomeric complexes. In these studies we observed that the reaction of the thiophilic silver(I) and mercury(II) ions with the isomeric NS2-macrocyclic ligands,  o  -L,  m  -L, and  p  -L (Chart ) incorporating ortho-, meta-, and para-xylyl subunits result in major structural differences between the respective metal complex products, especially when viewed at the supramolecular level. In particular, these complexes exhibited a range of topologies that included assemblies featuring very different flower-like cyclic oligomeric and leaf-like one-dimensional (1D) chain configurations. More recently, we also synthesized silver(I) and mercury(II) complexes of the  m  -L macrocycle which also gave rise to different coordination modes and topologies. For example, an unusual silver(I)/palladium(II) heterobinuclear complex forming a two-dimensional (2D) network was also obtained in which [cis-Cl2Pd( m  -L)] acts as a metalloligand.

elements.content: On the basis of the above results, we were motivated to extend our synthetic work to the preparation of further supramolecular network species incorporating the isomeric o -L, m -L, and p -L ligands. We now describe a comparative study of the synthesis and characterization of six new silver(I) supramolecular complexes of the above ligand series, with emphasis on the influence of changing the macrocyclic ring size (and hence its concomitant flexibility) on their potential for networking through exploiting the tendency of these thia-containing ligands to promote exocyclic metal coordination.
elements.clean_text: On the basis of the above results, we were motivated to extend our synthetic work to the preparation of further supramolecular network species incorporating the isomeric  o  -L,  m  -L, and  p  -L ligands. We now describe a comparative study of the synthesis and characterization of six new silver(I) supramolecular complexes of the above ligand series, with emphasis on the influence of changing the macrocyclic ring size (and hence its concomitant flexibility) on their potential for networking through exploiting the tendency of these thia-containing ligands to promote exocyclic metal coordination.

elements.content: Macrocycles o -L, m -L, and p -L were synthesized as described previously, and their structures were determined by single-crystal X-ray crystallography. Colorless crystals of m -L and p -L suitable for X-ray analysis were obtained by slow evaporation of a dichloromethane solution of each ligand. A colorless crystal of the hydronitrate salt, o -L·HNO3, was obtained by slow evaporation of a dichloromethane/methanol solution of o -L containing several drops of HNO3. The crystal structures of all three compounds are shown in Figure .
elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion

Crystal Structures of Macrocyclic Isomers ( o  -L,  m  -L, and  p  -L)

Macrocycles  o  -L,  m  -L, and  p  -L were synthesized as described previously, and their structures were determined by single-crystal X-ray crystallography. Colorless crystals of  m  -L and  p  -L suitable for X-ray analysis were obtained by slow evaporation of a dichloromethane solution of each ligand. A colorless crystal of the hydronitrate salt,  o  -L⋅HNO3, was obtained by slow evaporation of a dichloromethane/methanol solution of  o  -L containing several drops of HNO3. The crystal structures of all three compounds are shown in Figure .

elements.content: Crystal structures of (a) o -L·HNO3, (b) m -L, and (c) p -L. The HNO3 in o -L·HNO3 and hydrogen atoms are omitted.
elements.clean_text: 1  Crystal structures of (a)  o  -L⋅HNO3, (b)  m  -L, and (c)  p  -L. The HNO3 in  o  -L⋅HNO3 and hydrogen atoms are omitted.

elements.content: In o -L·HNO3, the two sulfur donors are oriented in an exodentate fashion, while the protonated nitrogen donor is arranged endodentate with respect to the ring cavity, with the macrocyclic ring adopting a somewhat twisted arrangement. In m -L, all NS2 donors are arranged exodentate with respect to the ring cavity, with the macrocyclic backbone again adopting a twisted arrangement. In p -L, the N and two S-donors are also arranged exodentate with respect to the ring cavity, but with the macrocycle adopting a flatter arrangement than occurs in the other two rings. The S1···S2 distances are 3.970 Å for o -L (HNO3 form), 5.231 Å for m -L, and 6.796 Å for p -L. The aliphatic ring segment corresponding to S1–C–C–N1–C–C–S2 adopts a gauche–gauche arrangement in o -L and m -L, while in p -L it shows an anti-anti arrangement in keeping with the more restricted flexibility of this latter ring.
elements.clean_text: In  o  -L⋅HNO3, the two sulfur donors are oriented in an exodentate fashion, while the protonated nitrogen donor is arranged endodentate with respect to the ring cavity, with the macrocyclic ring adopting a somewhat twisted arrangement. In  m  -L, all NS2 donors are arranged exodentate with respect to the ring cavity, with the macrocyclic backbone again adopting a twisted arrangement. In  p  -L, the N and two S-donors are also arranged exodentate with respect to the ring cavity, but with the macrocycle adopting a flatter arrangement than occurs in the other two rings. The S1⋅⋅⋅S2 distances are 3.970 Å for  o  -L (HNO3 form), 5.231 Å for  m  -L, and 6.796 Å for  p  -L. The aliphatic ring segment corresponding to S1-C-C-N1-C-C-S2 adopts a gauche-gauche arrangement in  o  -L and  m  -L, while in  p  -L it shows an anti-anti arrangement in keeping with the more restricted flexibility of this latter ring.

elements.content: Reactions of o -L with silver nitrate and perchlorate afforded three network complexes, [Ag6( o -L)6](NO3)6·0.5DMF·7H2O (1), [Ag8( o -L)8](ClO4)8 (2), and {[Ag2( o -L)2](ClO4)2·2CH3CN·CHCl3} n (3), showing different structures whose formation depends markedly on the anion present and in the latter two cases also the reaction temperature and solvent mixture employed (Scheme ). The resulting X-ray crystal structures of 1–3 are shown in Figures –, with selected geometric parameters presented in Tables –, respectively.
elements.clean_text:
Preparation and Structural Description of the Silver(I) Complexes of o-L (1-3)

Reactions of  o  -L with silver nitrate and perchlorate afforded three network complexes, [Ag6( o -L)6](NO3)6⋅0.5DMF⋅7H2O (1), [Ag8( o -L)8](ClO4)8 (2), and {[Ag2( o -L)2](ClO4)2⋅2CH3CN⋅CHCl3} n  (3), showing different structures whose formation depends markedly on the anion present and in the latter two cases also the reaction temperature and solvent mixture employed (Scheme ). The resulting X-ray crystal structures of 1-3 are shown in Figures -, with selected geometric parameters presented in Tables -, respectively.

The reaction of o -L with AgNO3 in a methanol–dichloromethane mixture yielded colorless crystals that proved suitable for crystallography. The structure determination confirmed that 1 has an unusual flower-like cyclic hexameric structure (Figure a,b); selected geometric parameters are presented in Table . The asymmetric unit contains three silver atoms and three coordinated ligands. There are three crystallographically different Ag atoms present with generally similar coordination environments. Each NS2 macrocycle is facially bonded to an Ag center as well as to a bridging S atom from an adjacent o -L to yield a distorted tetrahedral coordination environment (Figure c), with the bond angles around the metal ranging from 78.4(1) to 150.9(1)°; the large deviations from a regular tetrahedron in part appear to reflect the formation of reduced bite angles in the five-membered chelate rings formed by the S2N-donor set of bound o -L. The two nonbridging Ag–S bond lengths [2.587(1)–2.641(1) Å] are longer than those of the bridging Ag–S bond [2.454(1)–2.476(1) Å].

Flower-like cyclic hexameric structure of 1, [Ag6( o -L)6](NO3)6·0.5DMF·7H2O: (a) ball and stick representation, (b) space-filling representation with overlapped stick structure, (c) local coordination sphere of one silver(I) center, (d) side view, and (e) a skeleton of the Ag6S6 ring. Hydrogen atoms, solvent molecules, and anions are omitted except for the encapsulated NO3 – in (a) and (b).
elements.clean_text: 2  Flower-like cyclic hexameric structure of 1, [Ag6( o -L)6](NO3)6⋅0.5DMF⋅7H2O: (a) ball and stick representation, (b) space-filling representation with overlapped stick structure, (c) local coordination sphere of one silver(I) center, (d) side view, and (e) a skeleton of the Ag6S6 ring. Hydrogen atoms, solvent molecules, and anions are omitted except for the encapsulated NO3 - in (a) and (b).

elements.content: The repeating Ag–S–Ag–S bonding in the above structure leads to formation of an [Ag6( o -L)6]6+ metallaring embracing a central cavity (Figure a). The outer diameter of 1 is ∼15 Å with a thickness of ∼7.9 Å. The six ligand molecules in the cyclic backbone are arranged in an alternating up–down fashion (Figure d) and, as a consequence, the 12-membered Ag6S6 ring resembles a chair configuration (Figure e). Interestingly, the central cavity in this nanosized metallocycle acts as a receptor for a NO3 – anion (Figure a); the distances between individual Ag atoms and the closest nitrate oxygens (disordered) fall in the range 3.0–3.1 Å (dashed lines in Figure a). The remaining five NO3 – ions (not shown in Figure ) are positioned external to the cavity.
elements.clean_text: The repeating Ag-S-Ag-S bonding in the above structure leads to formation of an [Ag6( o  -L)6]6+ metallaring embracing a central cavity (Figure a). The outer diameter of 1 is ~15 Å with a thickness of ~7.9 Å. The six ligand molecules in the cyclic backbone are arranged in an alternating up-down fashion (Figure d) and, as a consequence, the 12-membered Ag6S6 ring resembles a chair configuration (Figure e). Interestingly, the central cavity in this nanosized metallocycle acts as a receptor for a NO3 - anion (Figure a); the distances between individual Ag atoms and the closest nitrate oxygens (disordered) fall in the range 3.0-3.1 Å (dashed lines in Figure a). The remaining five NO3 - ions (not shown in Figure ) are positioned external to the cavity.

elements.content: The formation of the cyclic hexamer 1 appears to be aided by the relatively flexible nature of o -L, with perhaps additional stabilization arising from its interaction with the central nitrate ion. Similar to the free ligand, the torsion angles for each S–CH2–CH2–N sequence correspond to a gauche conformation. The S···S distances for bonded o -L in 1 (4.219–4.169 Å) are longer than that found in free o -L (3.970 Å). In parallel to the formation of this complex, it is noted that we recently also reported an analogous cyclic hexamer formed from reaction of AgPF6 with o -L in which a PF6 – anion is encapsulated in the hexameric cavity.
elements.clean_text: The formation of the cyclic hexamer 1 appears to be aided by the relatively flexible nature of  o  -L, with perhaps additional stabilization arising from its interaction with the central nitrate ion. Similar to the free ligand, the torsion angles for each S-CH2-CH2-N sequence correspond to a gauche conformation. The S⋅⋅⋅S distances for bonded  o  -L in 1 (4.219-4.169 Å) are longer than that found in free  o  -L (3.970 Å). In parallel to the formation of this complex, it is noted that we recently also reported an analogous cyclic hexamer formed from reaction of AgPF6 with  o  -L in which a PF6 - anion is encapsulated in the hexameric cavity.

elements.content: Complexation of o -L with AgClO4 yielded the network complexes 2 and 3, with isolation of these products being dependent on the reaction conditions (Scheme ). At room temperature, and employing a methanol–dichloromethane solvent mixture, colorless crystals of [Ag8( o -L)8](ClO4)8 (2) were obtained. The crystal structure shows that 2 is octametallic, incorporating a cyclic hexameric structure with two pendent terminal “monomeric” units attached to the central ring in opposing positions via Sexo–Ag bonds (Figure a,b). Since 2 shows no symmetry, the entire octamer corresponds to the asymmetric unit. The conformation of the cyclic hexameric unit in 2 is similar to that found in 1. The bridging coordination of each o -L to silver (from Ag1 to Ag6 to form the hexameric ring core) occurs via a facial arrangement of the ligand’s S2N-donor set, with the coordination sphere of each Ag being completed by one sulfur atom from an adjacent o -L. The coordination geometry is distorted tetrahedral (Figure c), with the bond angles around each Ag falling in the range 78.5(1)–154.5(1)°; the large deviation from a regular tetrahedron appears, once again, largely a consequence the formation of 5-membered chelate rings (with their reduced bite angles) by this ligand’s S2N-donor set.

elements.content: Again, this nanosized metallacycle encircles a central cavity which in this complex is occupied by a ClO4 – anion. The shortest distances between individual Ag and O atoms fall in the range 2.825(2)–3.173(2) Å (dashed lines in Figure a). The other seven ClO4 – counterions occupy positions external to the cavity (not shown in Figure ). To the best of our knowledge the octametallic architecture found in this interesting metalloassembly is unique.

elements.content: The reaction of o -L with AgClO4 at 50 °C in an acetonitrile–chloroform mixture yielded colorless crystals of 3, that proved suitable for X-ray crystallography. The structure determination confirmed the {[Ag2(o-L)2](ClO4)2·2CH3CN·CHCl3} n stoichiometry and showed the structure to be a zigzag 1D coordination polymer (Figure ). The two crystallographically independent silver atoms (Ag1 and Ag2) present show no major differences in their coordination parameters (see Table ). Each silver center is again in a highly distorted tetrahedral environment defined by two S atoms and one N atom from a facially coordinated o -L macrocycle and one Sexo atom from an adjacent macrocycle resulting in the zigzag chain structure (Figure ). The bond angles around the Ag atoms vary from 79.5(1)° (N1–Ag1–S1) to 136.1(1)° (N1–Ag1–S4A) for Ag1, and from 80.8(1)° (N2–Ag2–S4) to 134.0(1)° (N2–Ag2–S2A) for Ag2, the large deviations from a regular tetrahedron again being clearly contributed to by the formation of 5-membered chelate rings by the S2N-donor set.

elements.content: X-ray analysis revealed that 4 is a 1D zigzag chain with formula [Ag( m -L)ClO4] n that incorporates a -( m -L)-Ag-( m -L)-Ag- motif (Figure ). Selected geometric parameters are presented in Table . Each Ag atom is again fac-coordinated by the NS2-donor set from one macrocycle which adopts a bent conformation and an S atom from an adjacent macrocycle to form the zigzag network. The structure is very similar to that found for 3 (derived from o -L) except that 4 shows higher symmetry; however, the asymmetric unit of 4 contains one macrocycle, one Ag atom, and one ClO4 – (not shown in Figure ), while that for 3 contains two macrocycles, two Ag atoms, and two ClO4 –.

Preparation and Structural Description of p-L Complexes (5 and 6)

The reaction of  p  -L with AgClO4 yielded a colorless crystalline product whose X-ray analysis confirmed it to be a mixture of two species: the infinite helical complex 5 and the discrete cyclic tetramer 6 (Scheme ). The X-ray structures of 5 and 6 are shown in Figures  and , with selected geometric parameters presented in Tables  and , respectively.

elements.content: X-ray analysis revealed that 5, {[Ag3( p -L)3](ClO4)3} n , is a 1D helical chain (Figure ). The asymmetric unit contains three p -L ligands coordinated to three Ag atoms in an alternating arrangement (Figure a); the helical framework in 5 is composed of o -L units and Ag atoms in a ( o -L)-Ag-( o -L)-Ag pattern (Figure b). The crystallographically independent Ag atoms (Ag1, Ag2, and Ag3), which act as linkers between the macrocyclic units, are three-coordinated and have similar coordination environments, being bound to one S and one N atom from a p -L ligand as well as to one S atom from an adjacent p -L ligand. Ag1 has a distorted trigonal planar coordination geometry, with the trigonal planar angles falling in the range 82.8(1)–155.3(1)°. The deviation from a regular trigonal plane reflects the presence of the five-membered chelate rings with their restricted bite angles together with possible steric hindrance between the pair of adjacent ligands linked by each Ag atom. No anions or solvent molecules are included in the coordination sphere. The conformation of p -L, which is the most restricted of the macrocyclic isomers, may play an important role in the formation of the helical structure by inhibiting coordination of both S-donors from a single macrocycle to a single metal ion.

elements.content: As illustrated in Figure c, the right (R)- and left (L)-handed helices are arranged in a parallel manner with partial interlacing of their structures occurring to give a pseudo 2D sheet array. In the packing, the individual (R)- and (L)-sheets are arranged alternatively (Figure d,e). The outer dimensions of the “square” channels present are approximately 10 × 11 Å2. Two asymmetric units (six ligands and six Ag atoms) define one pitch (∼14.4 Å) of the helix.

elements.content: X-ray analysis revealed that 6, [Ag4( o -L)4(ClO4)4], has the interesting cyclic tetrameric structure shown in Figure ; selected geometric parameters are presented in Table . The framework contains four crystallographically independent bridging p -L ligands coordinated to four Ag atoms through exocoordinated Ag–S and Ag–N bonds (Figure a). Each silver atom is four-coordinated, being bound by one S atom and one N atom from one p -L and one S atom from an adjacent p -L. The coordination sphere is completed by an O atom from monodentate ClO4 – [bond lengths: 2.710(2)–2.791(1) Å]; the latter falls within the range observed for other monodentate perchlorate complexes of silver. Each Ag coordination sphere is again distorted tetrahedral, with the tetrahedral angles spanning 82.5(1)–144.8(1)°. As a consequence, the repeating Ag-( p -L)-Ag-( p -L) network leads to a cyclic scaffold (Figure b,c) with a Ag4(SCCN)4 core that adopts a saddle shape (Figure d). This complex species shows similarities to other cyclic tetrameric silver(I) complexes of thiamacrocycles (L) with related [Ag4 L 4]4+ cores previously reported by us and others.

elements.content: The interaction of the isomeric series of NS2-donor macrocyclic ligands, o -L, m -L, and p -L, with silver nitrate and perchlorate provides a facile means for generating interesting new exo-coordination complexes, as exemplified by 1–6. From these results, it is concluded that variation of the macrocyclic-ring flexibilities in ligand isomers such as those employed in the present study, coupled with the use of exocoordination arising from the presence of thioether S donors, provides a useful and productive pathway to new complexes displaying unusual topologies.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusion

The interaction of the isomeric series of NS2-donor macrocyclic ligands,  o  -L,  m  -L, and  p  -L, with silver nitrate and perchlorate provides a facile means for generating interesting new exo-coordination complexes, as exemplified by 1-6. From these results, it is concluded that variation of the macrocyclic-ring flexibilities in ligand isomers such as those employed in the present study, coupled with the use of exocoordination arising from the presence of thioether S donors, provides a useful and productive pathway to new complexes displaying unusual topologies.

elements.content: All chemicals and solvents used in the syntheses were of reagent grade and were used without further purification. The electrospray ionization (ESI) mass spectra were obtained on a Thermo Scientific LCQ Fleet spectrometer. The Fourier transform infrared (FT-IR) spectra were measured with a Shimadzu FT-IR 8100 spectrometer. Unless stated otherwise each product obtained in this work was dried in a vacuum at 100 °C room before elemental analysis, which was carried out on a LECO CHNS-932 elemental analyzer. The X-ray powder diffraction (XRPD) experiments were performed in a transmission mode with a Bruker GADDS diffractometer equipped with graphite monochromated Cu Kα radiation (λ = 1.54073 Å). The NS2-donor macrocycles were prepared as described previously by us.
elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

General

All chemicals and solvents used in the syntheses were of reagent grade and were used without further purification. The electrospray ionization (ESI) mass spectra were obtained on a Thermo Scientific LCQ Fleet spectrometer. The Fourier transform infrared (FT-IR) spectra were measured with a Shimadzu FT-IR 8100 spectrometer. Unless stated otherwise each product obtained in this work was dried in a vacuum at 100 °C room before elemental analysis, which was carried out on a LECO CHNS-932 elemental analyzer. The X-ray powder diffraction (XRPD) experiments were performed in a transmission mode with a Bruker GADDS diffractometer equipped with graphite monochromated Cu Kα radiation (λ = 1.54073 Å). The NS2-donor macrocycles were prepared as described previously by us.

elements.content: AgClO4 (21 mg, 0.10 mmol) was dissolved in methanol (l.0 mL) and was added to the solution of p -L (20 mg, 0.08 mmol) in dichloromethane (l.0 mL). The white precipitate formed immediately and the precipitate was filtered off. Colorless crystalline product suitable for X-ray analysis was obtained by vapor diffusion of diethyl ether into a DMF (0.5 mL) solution of the precipitate. Single crystal analysis and XRPD results confirmed that the product is a two-component mixture: a 1D polymeric helical complex 5 and a discrete cyclic tetramer complex 6. Different crystals were selected for X-ray structure determinations, resulting in two different structures corresponding to 5 and 6.

Preparation of 5, {[Ag3(p-L)3](ClO4)3} n  and 6, [Ag4(p-L)4(ClO4)4]⋅3DMF

AgClO4 (21 mg, 0.10 mmol) was dissolved in methanol (l.0 mL) and was added to the solution of  p -L (20 mg, 0.08 mmol) in dichloromethane (l.0 mL). The white precipitate formed immediately and the precipitate was filtered off. Colorless crystalline product suitable for X-ray analysis was obtained by vapor diffusion of diethyl ether into a DMF (0.5 mL) solution of the precipitate. Single crystal analysis and XRPD results confirmed that the product is a two-component mixture: a 1D polymeric helical complex 5 and a discrete cyclic tetramer complex 6. Different crystals were selected for X-ray structure determinations, resulting in two different structures corresponding to 5 and 6.

elements.content: Data for m -L, p -L, 4, and 5 were collected on a Bruker Smart diffractometer equipped with a graphite monochromated Mo Kα (λ = 0.71073 Å) radiation source and a CCD detector. The frame data were processed to give structure factors using SAINT. The structure was solved by the direct method and refined by the full matrix least-squares method on F 2 for all data using SHELXTL software. The non-hydrogen atoms were refined anisotropically. The hydrogen atoms were placed in calculated positions and refined with a riding model with U iso constrained to be 1.2 times U eq of the parent atom.
elements.clean_text:
X-ray Crystallographic Analysis

Data for  m  -L,  p  -L, 4, and 5 were collected on a Bruker Smart diffractometer equipped with a graphite monochromated Mo Kα (λ = 0.71073 Å) radiation source and a CCD detector. The frame data were processed to give structure factors using SAINT. The structure was solved by the direct method and refined by the full matrix least-squares method on F 2 for all data using SHELXTL software. The non-hydrogen atoms were refined anisotropically. The hydrogen atoms were placed in calculated positions and refined with a riding model with U iso constrained to be 1.2 times U eq of the parent atom.

elements.content: Data for o -L, 1, 2, 3, and 6 were collected on a Bruker SMART APEX2 ULTRA diffractometer equipped with graphite monochromated Mo Kα radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å) generated by a rotating anode. Data collection, data reduction, and semiempirical absorption correction were carried out using the software package APEX2. All of the calculations for the structure determination were carried out using the SHELXTL package. In all cases, all non-hydrogen atoms were refined anisotropically and all hydrogen atoms except coordinated water molecules were placed in idealized positions and refined isotropically in a riding manner along with their respective parent atoms. For coordinated water molecules, the initial positions of the hydrogen atoms were obtained from difference electron density maps and refined with riding constraints. In 1, two water molecules, one DMF molecule, and one nitrate ion in the lattice are disordered. Since the lattice solvent (12 DMF) molecules in 2 are highly disordered, the contribution of solvent electron density was removed by the SQUEEZE routine in PLATON. Relevant crystal data collection and refinement data for the crystal structures are summarized in Table .

IR (KBr, cm-1): 3336 (w), 2933 (w), 1662 (m), 1456 (m), 1085 (s, ClO4 -), 957 (m), 775 (m), 557 (m). Anal. Calc. for C24H34N2S4Ag2Cl2O8: C, 32.27; H, 3.84; N, 3.14; S, 14.35. Found: C, 32.69; H, 3.41; N, 3.11; S, 14.67%.

Preparation of 4, {[Ag(m-L)]ClO4⋅CH2Cl2} n  

AgClO4 (21 mg, 0.10 mmol) was dissolved in methanol (l.0 mL) and was added to the solution of  m -L (20 mg, 0.08 mmol) in dichloromethane (l.0 mL). A white precipitate formed immediately and this was filtered off. Colorless crystalline 4 suitable for X-ray analysis was obtained by vapor diffusion of diethyl ether into a DMF (0.5 mL) solution of the precipitate. The crystals were dried under a vacuum at 50 °C before elemental analysis. Yield: 88%. IR (KBr, cm-1): 3288 (w), 2923 (w), 2850 (w), 2356 (m), 1460 (m), 1087 (s, ClO4 -), 908 (m), 717 (m), 622 (m). Anal. Calc. for C12H17NS2AgClO4: C, 32.26; H, 3.84; N, 3.14; S, 14.36. Found: C, 32.02; H, 3.76; N, 3.21; S, 13.97%.

Preparation of 5, {[Ag3(p-L)3](ClO4)3} n  and 6, [Ag4(p-L)4(ClO4)4]⋅3DMF

AgClO4 (21 mg, 0.10 mmol) was dissolved in methanol (l.0 mL) and was added to the solution of  p -L (20 mg, 0.08 mmol) in dichloromethane (l.0 mL). The white precipitate formed immediately and the precipitate was filtered off. Colorless crystalline product suitable for X-ray analysis was obtained by vapor diffusion of diethyl ether into a DMF (0.5 mL) solution of the precipitate. Single crystal analysis and XRPD results confirmed that the product is a two-component mixture: a 1D polymeric helical complex 5 and a discrete cyclic tetramer complex 6. Different crystals were selected for X-ray structure determinations, resulting in two different structures corresponding to 5 and 6.

cln_elements.content: The repeating Ag–S–Ag–S bonding in the above structure leads to formation of an [Ag6( o -L)6]6+ metallaring embracing a central cavity (Figure a). The outer diameter of 1 is ∼15 Å with a thickness of ∼7.9 Å. The six ligand molecules in the cyclic backbone are arranged in an alternating up–down fashion (Figure d) and, as a consequence, the 12-membered Ag6S6 ring resembles a chair configuration (Figure e). Interestingly, the central cavity in this nanosized metallocycle acts as a receptor for a NO3 – anion (Figure a); the distances between individual Ag atoms and the closest nitrate oxygens (disordered) fall in the range 3.0–3.1 Å (dashed lines in Figure a). The remaining five NO3 – ions (not shown in Figure ) are positioned external to the cavity.

The outer diameter of 1 is ~15 Å with a thickness of ~7.9 Å. The six ligand molecules in the cyclic backbone are arranged in an alternating up-down fashion (Figure d) and, as a consequence, the 12-membered Ag6S6 ring resembles a chair configuration (Figure e). Interestingly, the central cavity in this nanosized metallocycle acts as a receptor for a NO3 - anion (Figure a); the distances between individual Ag atoms and the closest nitrate oxygens (disordered) fall in the range 3.0-3.1 Å (dashed lines in Figure a). The remaining five NO3 - ions (not shown in Figure ) are positioned external to the cavity.
